{"comments": {"id": 27200, "count": 279, "talk_id": 2583}, "threadId": 27200, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2583", "description": ""We're not in a clean energy revolution; we're in a clean energy crisis," says climate policy expert Michael Shellenberger. His surprising solution: nuclear. In this passionate talk, he explains why it's time to overcome longstanding fears of the technology, and why he and other environmentalists believe it's past time to embrace nuclear as a viable and desirable source of clean power.", "event": "TEDSummit", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Michael Shellenberger: How fear of nuclear power is hurting the environment", "slug": "michael_shellenberger_how_fear_of_nuclear_power_is_hurting_the_environment", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "2989", "slug": "michael_shellenberger", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Michael", "lastname": "Shellenberger", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Climate policy expert", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/77bc009175ec14e4aa367be3f1b99fe71779e09e_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Michael Shellenberger is a global thinker on energy, technology and the environment.", "whylisten": "

Michael Shellenberger is co-founder and Senior Fellow at the Breakthrough Institute, where he was president from 2003 to 2015, and a co-author of the Ecomodernist Manifesto.

Over the last decade, Shellenberger and his colleagues have constructed a new paradigm that views prosperity, cheap energy and nuclear power as the keys to environmental progress. A book he co-wrote (with Ted Nordhaus) in 2007, Break Through: From the Death of Environmentalism to the Politics of Possibility, was called by Wired magazine "the best thing to happen to environmentalism since Rachel Carson's Silent Spring," while Time magazine called him a "hero of the environment." In the 1990s, he helped protect the last significant groves of old-growth redwoods still in private hands and bring about labor improvements to Nike factories in Asia.

The manifesto offers a sweeping vision of how humans can address ecological crises while lifting all humans out of poverty.", "note": "", "link_url": "http://www.ecomodernism.org/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "WATCH", "headline": "*Pandora’s Promise*", "blurb": "In 2013, I was one of the environmentalists featured in the award-winning documentary, *Pandora's Promise*, who changed their minds about nuclear energy. The film sparked and international debate and won numerous awards. "When was the last time you saw a documentary that fundamentally changed the way you think?" wrote Entertainment Weekly. You can watch *Pandora’s Promise* on Netflix or YouTube.", "note": "Robert Stone 2013", "link_url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kBMj-96hols", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Whole Earth Discipline*", "blurb": "I was mesmerized by [Stewart Brand’s 2009 TED talk](https://www.ted.com/talks/stewart_brand_proclaims_4_environmental_heresies) on the same subject but I hadn’t really become pro-nuclear until I read his book. I was surprised to learn how modest the health impacts of radiation exposure were. But what was really moving was the way Stewart made the case for nuclear within the larger context of lifting all humans out of poverty.", "note": "Stewart Brand Viking Adult, 2009", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Whole-Earth-Discipline-Ecopragmatist-Manifesto/dp/0670021210/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""The Liberation of Nature"", "blurb": ""The Liberation of Nature" and "Renewable and Nuclear Heresies" crystallized my thinking more than any other two articles. In the first, Ausubel shows how humans save nature -- we don’t just destroy it. In the second, he explains why energy dense fuels have, by their physical nature, fewer environmental impacts. The broad sweep of human development and its impact on the environment seems obvious after you read these articles. ", "note": "Jesse Ausubel *Daedalus*, 1996", "link_url": "http://phe.rockefeller.edu/Daedalus/Liberation/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""Renewable and Nuclear Heresies"", "blurb": " ", "note": "Jesse Ausubel *Nuclear Governance, Economy and Ecology*, 2007", "link_url": "http://phe.rockefeller.edu/docs/HeresiesFinal.pdf", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}]}]}, "more_resources": [{"status": "approved", "headline": "Environmental Progress", "blurb": "We used to believe solar and wind could solve climate change and end poverty. Jacobson", "title": "Debate: Does the world need nuclear energy?", "duration": 1379.0, "slug": "debate_does_the_world_need_nuclear_energy", "viewed_count": 1447973}, {"id": "2650", "hero": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/talkstar-photos/uploads/1dff1169-dafe-4f49-9c67-91822e38ea4e/ErikaGregory_2016W-embed.jpg", "speaker": "Erika Gregory", "title": "The world doesn't need more nuclear weapons", "duration": 899.0, "slug": "erika_gregory_the_world_doesn_t_need_more_nuclear_weapons", "viewed_count": 959652}, {"id": "767", "hero": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/150046_800x600.jpg", "speaker": "Bill Gates", "title": "Innovating to zero!", "duration": 1669.0, "slug": "bill_gates", "viewed_count": 4918410}], "slug": "michael_shellenberger_how_fear_of_nuclear_power_is_hurting_the_environment", "speakers": [{"id": "2989", "slug": "michael_shellenberger", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Michael", "lastname": "Shellenberger", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Climate policy expert", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/77bc009175ec14e4aa367be3f1b99fe71779e09e_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Michael Shellenberger is a global thinker on energy, technology and the environment.", "whylisten": "

Michael Shellenberger is co-founder and Senior Fellow at the Breakthrough Institute, where he was president from 2003 to 2015, and a co-author of the Ecomodernist Manifesto.

Over the last decade, Shellenberger and his colleagues have constructed a new paradigm that views prosperity, cheap energy and nuclear power as the keys to environmental progress. A book he co-wrote (with Ted Nordhaus) in 2007, Break Through: From the Death of Environmentalism to the Politics of Possibility, was called by Wired magazine "the best thing to happen to environmentalism since Rachel Carson's Silent Spring," while Time magazine called him a "hero of the environment." In the 1990s, he helped protect the last significant groves of old-growth redwoods still in private hands and bring about labor improvements to Nike factories in Asia.

author: Michael_Shellenberger;
title: How fear of nuclear power is hurting the environment
